ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: We learned a lot about genes
I developed more of an appreciation for Genes and Development, and Ecology and Evolutionary Biology. I became better able to write a scientific proposal and read scientific articles.

Knowledge about genetics, developmental biology, evolutionary biology and ecology.
How to write a proposal and paper

I think the most important skill that I developed the most after this course was my ability to investigate. After the course I feel more confident on where to look for sources, as well as selecting those that are more suitable and trust worthy.
I learned about genetics, development, ecology, and evolution, as well as how to navigate databases and aggregate research for relevant medical information.

I learned so much about the evolution of homologues. It is relevant to the career that I wish to follow, in medicine, because many mechanisms in the body, whether proteins or at a larger scale, can be understood better by viewing our bodies as the latest stage in a long evolutionary process, rather than a single "still image" in the present time. I learned that two theses that Darwin posited in The Origin of Species were that all species evolved from a common ancestor, and natural selection. Moreover, I learned about genetic drift, gene flow, and other factors that affect the propagation of genetic traits in a population. Another key piece of information was the use of Yamanaka factors to make pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs), which was a groundbreaking mechanism.
I continued my development in the field of biology

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This is a great course! The content is highly condensed, but that is to be expected considering the format of summer session. Professor Hartman and Professor Near were approachable and responsive. I appreciate how open they both were to answering questions about content and providing clarification about assignment feedback.

I think the strengths of this course are the final projects of each half, because they are very well explained, and also they are very easy to do with the information that is seen during class. I don't think there are weaknesses.
Professors were helpful and took time to explain and elaborate concepts, and the course was mostly paced well. Lectures were engaging and assignment turnaround was reasonable.
The course provided excellent visual presentations, the were easy to follow in class and out of class. I enjoy visual learning, so this was my ideal.
I thought that Professor Hartman could have been more engaging

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! The material was interesting and it gave me a good overview of some critical concepts for Genes and Development and Ecology and Evolutionary Biology that will be useful for future courses in biology. Professor Hartman and Professor Near are great.

Yes, I would totally recommend this course to someone that has a basic knowledge of biology because it can help them expand their knowledge in a lot of directions since the course covers a lot of topics.
Yes, it was interesting and a reasonable part of biology track.
Yes, absolutely! Incredible instructors, fascinating subject matter.
Yes if they are interested in biology

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: I will use my improved understanding of Genes and Development and proposal-writing in future biology courses and in lab work.
I will use the investigation skills that I learned in this class in future investigations.

I will remember the methods used to make iPSCs, and other remarkable discoveries that Dr. Hartman described. Also, I learned how to use genetics databases, a skill I am surprised I never gained before. Very grateful for this experience.
